projects.description:
An honours project made for my 2022 Honours Year; this is the practical component. 
 This game is a companion piece to my Honours thesis on redirecting the perception of the NPC beyond simply being a mechanical tool or vestibule for story, to instead see them as affective entities in their own right.

projects.title: Exploring the post-human affective NPC using character-centric game design
projects.subtitle: Honours submission
projects.description: Abstract: The construct of the non-player character (or NPC), mechanically, is seen in most modern video games and is an important point of interaction for players. In this paper we take a look at an affective-based approach to examining NPCs based on both their capacity for companionship with the player ascribed through affect theory, as well as their existence as a self-impelled entity through post-human performativity theory. With this approach in mind, we have synthesised a gameplay experience with the companionship of the NPC as a driving force to examine how such a relationship can be defined. In this gameplay, the player is bound to a character that they become emotionally attached to throughout the narrative. We identify a temporal approach to NPC relationships that may enhance interactions with characters by making them non-repeatable through narrative intervention.

projects.title: Is kicking a robot dog morally wrong, or morally permissible?
projects.subtitle: Ethics in Computer Science (COMP4920) assignment
projects.description: An assignment to ponder ethical considerations in computer science: in this assignment I argue against the act of harming a robot dog as unvirtuous. In any computer science setting, I believe it is imperative that the engineers behind the work must be self-aware about these considerations.
